div.p:
There remaine certaine
things but a few true
ly, which are to bee ex
pounded unto you (deere
ly beloved) the which
partely appertayne to the instituti
on of the Ecclesiasticall ministerie
and preservation thereof, there are
partelie certaine percular ordinaun
ces of the Church which the Church
can not want. Whereof in this last
Sermon of this Decade, so farre
as the Lorde shall give mee grace to
speake, I intende as briefly as I can
to intreate.

First of all we must know that the
Lorde our God hath not burdened his
church with over manie lawes & in
stitutions, but hath let downe a fewe
easily to be numbered, & those not costly,
nor intricate, nor long, but profitable,
simple, plaine and short.

In time past, when as under the law
the Lord appointed unto the people a
costly and sumptuous worshipping of
him, not withstanding al things there
in were certaine, numerable, and mo
derate: neyther woulde he have anie
thing added to, or taken from it at the
pleasure of men, or to bee otherwise b
led than he had appointed.

Who then will thinke, that after
the abrogating of the Lawe, the Lord
would deliver unto the Church of his
new people, a sumptuous and an infi
nite discipline? Wherefore it is partly
the couetousnesse of the Pastours and
estates of the Church, and partly the
monstrous superstition of the common
people, that hath made everie thing for
sumptuous, and infinite in the church.
Let us sticke unto this, that the Lord
our GOD hath instituted in his
Church, but verie fewe thinges, and
such as are necessarie: and therefore
we ought all to indeavour, that the
church be not over-burdened with tra
ditions and institutions, which procee
ded not from GOD himselfe. The
Church of God is gorgeously enough
decked and furnished, if she retaine and
keep the institutions of her God and
Lorde.

The chiefe and principall poyntes
of the Godlinesse of the Church of
GOD, are the sincere teaching of
the lawe and the Prophetes, of Christ
and the Apostles, faithfull Prayer of
fered unto her onely GOD thorough
Christ alone, a religious and lawfull,
administration & receiving of Christes
sacramets wehreof we have intreated
hitherto through the Decades. Here
unto belongeth Charitie also, which
is a communicating of riches, or well
doing, whereof wee have saide some
what alreadie in the first Decade, and
will have somewhat else in this Ser
mon.

Neyther doeth Luke in the Actes
make mention of any other things, de
scribing what manner of Church the
faithfull primitive Church of Christe
was, being founded by the Apostles, &
what were the principal points thereof.
They were continuing, sayeth he, in
the doctrine of the Apostles, and in
communicating, and in breaking of
bread and in prayer. Under these few
points all godlinesse is comprised. Un
to the Ecclesiastical ministery are joy
ned these that folow. Christian schooles
have the first place, which being foorth
a plentifull increase of Prophetes or
Ministers of the Church. All nations
unles they were altogether barbarous
have understoode that without schooles
no kingdomes or common weales can
happily be maintained. And therefore
not onely Moses in the book of Ge
nesis, but also Strabo in the 17. booke
of his Geographie, reporteth how that
among the Egyptians were instituted
most famous Colledges for Priestes &
Philosophers. Histories also make
mention, that the most noble men of al
the worlde, travayled into Egypt to
obtaine wisedome, in which number
Plato also is saide to be the first of the
chiefe and principall among the Phil
losophers.

Neither is it unadvisedly written
in the booke of the Kinges, that Salo
mon excelled the wise men of the E
gyptians in wisedome. And not onely
the Egyptians, but also the Pale
stines, a Nation more famous for
warres than for learning, are sayde
to have had their Priests, of whom
they asked cousell in matters of doubt,
as writeth Samuel in his holie Hi
storie.

And Daniel also witnesseth, that
the Babylonians had moste famous
Schooles, as also had the Medes and
Persians, from whence sprang foorth
their Magi, I would saye wise men,
notable in all parties of Philosophie.
I neede not to speake any thing of the
Greekes and Romanes, since there
is no man but knoweth their most fa
mous Citie of Athens, which is so
much spoken of by all learned men.
and also the goodly Colledges of their
Priests and Southsayers. But o
mitting foreine examples, let us al
ledge our owne or such as are Ecclesi
asticall.

God, who gave unto his people, a
moste absolute fourme of an happie
Common weale and kingdome, distri
buted schooles through fortie and eight
townes of the realme. Those townes
by reason of the Philosophy Levits,
were called Leviticall. For hee had
consecrated all the Leviticall Tribe,
unto the Priesthood and to studies:
Not for that it was not also lawful for
Gentlemen of other Tribes to studie
Philosophie or wisedome: but because
the Levites were peculiarlie appoin
ted unto holy studies.

For it is evident, that Clay and Da
niel, two of the most bright lights of
them that prophecied were of the tribe
of Juda. Other Tribes also have
brought foorth mi right singular in all
kind of knowledge. And those townes
likewise were called Leviticall and
Priestly, not that Preists onely dwelt
in them, but because they had Syna
gogues in them.

.
But at the tabernacle in Silo, and spe
cially in the city of Jerusale there was
a schoole surpassing all other, & in ma
ner of an universitie, as they call them
now adaies.

And the same holie historie witnes
seth that most famous men had the go
vernment of those schooles. For wee
read in Kama that Samuel, who was
the verie chiefest in all wisedome, god
lines, and learning, was governour
and principal of Naioth, that is to say,
ye Burse (as they terme it) or Colledge
of Prophetes. Helias and Heliieus
the most cleare lightes of the Church
of Israel, were rules over the schoole
of Hierico and Gilgal. That naugh
tie Jeroboam did pul downe ye schooles
and tread under foote the order of the
Priests, and places without all choice
some that were of the refuse of the
people in their places.

But the men of God Helias and He
liseus knew wel, that without schooles
the sound docrine could not flourish or
be preserved: and therefore they ap
plyed their selves wholly to the renu
ing of schooes. And when lawfull tri
butes were denied them, being by wic
ked Princes bestowed upon flatterers
and bellies, that is to say, priests of the
Tools of calves & of Baal: yet it came
to passe by the goodnes of the Lord, that
some good men bestowed somewhat
upo such as were desirous of learning,
who holding them selves contented
with a meane living, behaved them
selves valianily in that most corrupt
age. But those notable men, those wise
men & prophetes, who had the govern
met over schooles, were called fathers,
whereuppon also their disciples and
scholers were termed the sonnes of the
prophetes.

Amos and Jeremiei call them Para
sites. for, saith Amos, I am no pro
phet, neither the sonne of a Prophet,
to wit, not brought up in the know
ledge of liberall artes. And the same
man saieth againe: I have raysed up
of your sonnes for Prophetes, and of
your young me for Nazarites. But Je
remie commandeth also the manner of
them that studied, which in his lamen
tations he be wayleth to be altogether
perished in the captivitie. Further
more, they are called the sonnes of the
Prophets, for the affection which they
bare towards their schoole maisters, as
if they had beene their parents, and for
their obedience and daylie studie to
wardes them.

But how much the more noble and
wise the Princes were, so much the
more diligence they imployed in repai
ring schooles, and restoring Ecclesiasti
ciall order. Which a man may see, not
in David and Salomon onely, but al
so in Jolaphat, Ezechias, and Josias,
who were most vertuous and most
happie Princes. In the captivitie and
after the captivitie of Babylon, the
Lordes people was dispersed and scat
tered into many kingdomes farre and
wide. But whither to ever they were
carried, they erected scholes or synago
gues. and when the citie of Jerusalem
was restored, then they often came un
to the same. For therefore the Actes
of the Apostles make mention, that at
what time Saint Paul preached the
worde of God among the Gentiles,
hee went into the Synagogues and
taught.

And Saint James the Apostle
sayeth, Moses in olde time hath in
everie citie them that preach him in
the synagogues. Where he speaketh
not of the cities of Judea and Galilee,
but of the cities of the Gentiles, in Sy
ria, Cilicia and Asia. But that which
we reade in the Actes doth shewe that
they being dispersed and scattered a
broad, did sometime come unto the holy
citie of Jerusalem. There were dwel
ling at Jerusalem certaine Jewes reli
ious men, of all nations that are un
der heaven. And that also which saint
Paule reciteth of him selfe confirmeth
the same, that being born free in the ci
tie of Tharsus, he travelled to Jerusa
lem unto Gamaliels feete, that is to
say, to the intent to heare the instructi
on, and to be a scholer under Gamaliel,
So likewise we read that at Jerusa
lem there were Colledges or Synago
gues of the Livertines, Cyrenians, A
lerandrines, Cilicians, and Asians.

This use of scholes continued until
Christes time, yea, and after his as
cension into the heavens, almost until
the destruction of the citie, although in
the mean time it may appeare to have
beene sundrie times depraved.

Christ also the sonne of God, our
king and high Bishoppe, he himelfe
instituted the most famous schole of al
other, calling thereunto the twelve A
postles, and the seventie disciples, cho
sen men, I say, to the number of foure
score and two. Pea, the Apostles them
selves drew unto them very many dis
ciples, and first of all Saint Paul the
most chosen instrument of God to con
vert the Gentiles, is read to have had
in his companie, Sopater of Berrhee,
Luke of Antioch, Marke of Jerusalem,
Barnabas, Eylua or Sylvanus, Caius
and Timothie, Aristarchus and Secun
dus , Tychicus and Prophimus, Fitus
and Linus, Erescens and Epaphras, Ar
chippus and Philemon, Epaphroditus
and Artemas, and many other.

He hath also commended most dili
gently unto good men, the studious, and
the ministers of the Churches, exhor
ting all men unto liberalitie, that they
may want nothing. Aud writing unto
Titus: Bring diligentlye sayeth hee,
Zenas the Lawyer and Apollo, upon
their waye, that they may want no
thing.

Moreover it may bee gathered by
plaine and manifest proofes out of the
thirteenth chapter of the Actes, that
there was a verie famous and that an
Apostolique schoole at Antioch in Sy
ria. Eusebius also of Cesarea aboun
dantly witnesseth what noble schooles
were at Alexandria in Egypt, and in
other renouned churches. And wee
have also declared the same more at
large, when time served, in a booke
which we have written of the institu
tion of Bishops.

But in processe of time when all
things appertaining to the Church be
ganne to decline to the worsse, Ecclesi
asticall schooles also degenerated into
Abbaies, or into Colledges of Canons
and Monkes.

But of all these thinges whereof
wee have spoken, I thinke it not un
knowen unto any man, that schooles
doe principally belong to the preser
vation of the Church, and the main
tenance of the holie ministerie, in
which schooles good artes might be ex
ercised, verie profitable for the fur
theraunce of the studie of the holie
Scriptures: of which forte chiefest of
all are the studies and knowledge of
holy tongues, of Logick, naturall Phi
losophie, and the Mathematicks, and
these moderately knowen, and directed
unto the certaine scope and ende of
Godlinesse. For a man may some
time finde wittes worne and wared
olde in diverse Artes and disciplines,
howbeit not once medling or inured
with holy exercises and studies. But
I would to God that the wicked be
ing too much glutted with prophane
studie, would also leave to contemne
holy Scriptures as things plaine bar
barous.

A man also may finde some wits
so busied in the studie of the Mathema
tickes, that they are more meete to be
masters of buildings, then governours
or pastours of Churches. Yea they
are so farre crept into the studie of A
stronome, and the Astronomers hea
ven, that they quite forget the blessed
heaven, which is the seat of the blessed
Saintes, any thing to pertaine unto
them, and that they should be suffici
ently happy if they can but once attein
unto the knowledge of the motion of
the visible heaven, and to the course of
the Starres. As for those that meddle
overmuch with the studie of Philoso
phie, and the trifles of Logicke, and
the rules of Rhetorick, never atteine
unto anie ende, nor earnestly thinke
upon the bestowing of their travels to
the edifying of the Church : common
ly they become contentious and braw
ling disputers for the most part, and
arrogant controllers: unto whome
nothing seemeth to be neately and apt
ly enough, eyther spoken or doone of
others, but that which is tempered and
as it were tuned to their great con
ceyving heades, and so agreeing with
prescript rules, that they swarve not
therefrom, no not so much as a haires
bredth.

These men snarle and intangle all
things with their doltish disputations
pusting out nothing else but quarrel
ling controversies, taking upon them
most arrogantly to judge all mens do
inges and sayinges what soever, yea,
though they be good & tollerable, they
snappe at them, and maliciously cavill
against them, being rather vaine bab
lers, than Philosophers, yea, the very
plagues of scholes and churches: who
spit out the poyson of debates, conten
tions, variances, strifes and divisions,
at and into the Church. Against these
S. Paul the Apostle to Timothie see
meth to speake.

For after hee had briefly set downe
the summe of sound doctrine, he addeth
thereupon. This teach and exhort,
whosoever teacheth otherwise, and
holdeth not him selfe contented
with the healthfull woorde of our
Lord lesus Christ, and the doctrine
which is according unto godlinesse,
he is puffed uppe, knowing nothing,
but spending his time about que
stions and contention, in woordes,
whereof groweth hakred, strife, slan
der, evill suspicions, vaine conflictes,
of men corrupt in heart, and destitute
of the trueth, which suppose gaine, to
be godlinesse. Avoyde the companie
of such.

Truely it never went well with
the church, when learned and studious
men forsaking the plainenesse and
purenesse of the worde of God, turned
their eyes another way, and aimed
not at the worde of God alone. They
in auncient time, did not contemne the
worde of God: but in the meane while
they attributed more to traditions tha
was convenient.

But by that meanes they both gave
occasion unto errours, and confirmed
such abuses as were alreadie brought
in. Certaine yeares past and gone,
Gratian and Lombarde, with other
ecclesiasticall writers, went about to
make an agreement of opinions, and to
gather together a perfect and certaine
summe of divinity. But therby they did
not only carrie the schooles away from
the scriptures, but also intruded strage
doctrines into the Church.

After these there followed Alex
ander, Albertus, and Thomas, who
not onely depended upon those senten
ces, and commended them unto others
but also endevoured to mingle Philo
sophie with Divinitie, and to couch
them together into one bodie. And
hereof it came to passe that we had so
many wayes and sectes, so many pud
dles crauling full of frogges, so many
schooles, so many Abbayes, so manie
sophisters.

And if at this day likewise we con
tinue unhappily to couple Philosophie
with the holie scriptures, and super
stitiously tall them into disputation,
and to call them unto examination by,
humane rules, or to the handling by
artes, then shall we also corrupt them
in the scholes, perverting the integri
tie of the Apostolique doctrine, to the
great detriment of the church. In the
meane while, certaine it is that good
Artes and learning do make much un
to perspicvitie and plainnesse, but mo
derately ad religiously applyed with
judgement, so that the scriptures may
have the upper hande, and all other
Artes obey the same.

Wherefore, let pure godlinesse bee
taught in Ecclesiasticall schooles, yea,
let godlinesse bee the ende of all our
studies : at the first let the studious be
diligently taught the Catechisme, and
let them never rest untill such time
as they have learned it perfectly and
made it familiar unto theselves: the
let this young begunne godlinesse bee
daily increased with Lectures and ho
ly Sermons: Let the writinges of the
holy Evangelists and Apostles bee al
wayes reade unto them, that they
may become perfecte in them in due
season : let them also commodiously
learne the tongues and good Arts, and
let them be exercised in writing and
reasoning.

But above all, let dissolutenesse
and wantonnesse hee banished out of
the godly instituted and Christian
schooles. Let discipline, yea, though
it bee somewhat sharpe, flourish. For
if youth bee corrupted in the schooles,
and grow up in that corruption, what
I pray you shall wee looke for at their
handes, when they be set in autoritie
over the Church? Let us not believe
that they will be the salt of the church,
who as they are most dissolute & bloc
kish, so can they not abide sharpenesse
in other. Shall we thinke that they
will become lightes of the church, who
doe themselves hate the light, and are
delighted in darkenesse, and in the
workes of darknesse? Wherefore, that
which the sonnes of Helie were in the
church of Israel, the same shall be and
are the corrupt sons of the Prophetes
in the church of Christ. They therfore
shall likewise perish with the people
which are committed unto them. And
therefore now adayes there is great
offence committed thorough too much
lenitie in the schooles, a mischief which
will never be washed away. For a
man shall come into many schooles,
where he shall thinke he seeth so many
souldiers and rustians, no scholers and
students, whom they commonly call
clearkes.

Neyther their fare, neyther their
apparell, neyther their manners, ney,
ther their woordes, neyther their
deedes, declare them to be of any good
disposition, honest, or studious. I
knowe that much is to be ascribed
unto our unhappie and most dissolute
age, in which the stubborn and rebelli
ous will not hearken to the counsell of
the elders: and againe I knowe, that
there are great offences committed
through the negligence and fonde gen
tlenesse of them that are in authoritie.

But for as much as the welfare of
the Church consisteth of schooles well
ordered, we ought all of us to use great
diligence, that in this behalf there may
no offence bee committed through our
carelesnesse and negligence.

This much have I saide concer
ning Ecclesiasticall schooles, in as few
woordes as might conveniently: of
which I have intreated more at large
in my booke of the institution of By
shops.

Furthermore, to the end that schooles
with ye whole ministery may be main
tained, togither with al holy buildings
and Ecclesiasticall charges, there nee
deth to be some good wealth and abili
tie correspondent.

This place therfore admonisheth us
to say somewhat concerning Ecclesi
asticall goods. God in that common
welth which he would have to ercell al
other as best furnished with all things
necessarie, appointed standing fees to
be paid unto the holy ministerie of the
common charege, to wit, the tithes, the
first fruites, and sundrie other kinds of
offeringes.

These thinges are in the lawe ex
pressed by Moses the man of God in
many wordes: who nothing feared,
least for handling of that matter hee
should be accused of greedie desire, or
covetousnesse. For those thinges
which God commaunded him to de
clare plainely to the people, hee utte
red unto them faithfully. Yea, the
lawe of nature commaundeth to re
warde him that taketh paine, and to
maintaine common chareges by com
mon contribution. And those reve
nues or tributes that were publique
lie gathered, were not bestowed but
to publique uses. For they were partly
give to the ministers for their ministe
ry & service, partly they were disbursed
upon publique buildinges & holy char
ges, and part was imployed to the re
liefe of the poore.

And although by the newe Testa
ment the Levitical law with ye whole
Priesthood be abrogated, notwithstan
ding it is certaine that ye same univer
sall law, which commandeth that pub
lique charges should bee levied by pub
lique contributions, is not abolished.

For we read that our Lorde Jesus
Christe, although hee lived not of the
tenths & revenves of the Priestes, yet
lived he of the cotributions of the god
ly. For hee executed a publique functi
on. And sending his disciples abroade
to preach, expressely saith unto them: I
would not have you to be carefull for
foode and apparell: for the labourer is
worthie of his hire.

Wherefore the primitive Church
which the Apostles have gathered to
Christ, bestowed their houses, landes
and money for the preservation of the
ministerie, and other things necessarie
for the Church.

The Priestes and Levites at that
time possessed the holy revenves, not
giving one iote to the Apostolique
Church, which rather they wished
might sterve for hunger. But the godly
and faithfull people knewe very well,
that earthly substance and riches were
very necessarie for the preservation of
the Church.

For God hath appointed men & not
Angels to be ministers of the Church:
and hath recommended poore men un
to the Church to stande in his stead.

But they as men are wout to doe,
lacke & are destitute of many thinges,
wherefore good men through the moti
on of the holy Ghost, doe contribute to
gether, & bestow money, houses, lands,
and other goods, wherby both the poore
and also the holy ministerie may bee
maintained.

And hereupon also it is evident that
the Church of the people of the new te
stament, had ever since ye time of Christ
and the Apostles, goods and possessions
publikely gathered and received, and
also layde out and bestowed them a
gaine for publique and common com
moditie.

Gregorie the first of that name, bi
shoppe of Rome, sayth that it was the
custome in his time and also before his
time, that there ought to be foure por
tions or parts of the church of God.

One for the bishop and his familie,
another for the clergy, the third for the
poore, and the fourth for the repayring
of Churches.

But there are a great many that say
that a bishoppe ought not to receive
wages of ye church. Let us therfore ex
amine what Christ and his Apostles do
teach us touching that matter. Christ
our Lorde, who never committed anie
unjust thing, received, as it is reade,
maintenance from such women as he
taught, who ministred unto him of
their substace. He also sending his dis
ciples abroad, and willing them not to
be carefull for meate and drinke, and
raiment, saith further, The labourer is
worthie of his hire.

The Lord judgeth it to be worthie,
meete, & right, to minister necessaries
unto preachers. Wherefore they do no
unworthy deede which receive wages,
thereby to provide necessaries for them
selves and their family: yea, he compa
reth preachers not to idle bellies, not to
them ye eate freely of other mens bread,
neither to beggers, but to laborers. For
as ye Lord setteth down in ye law, how
that it is a great offence to deny labo
rers their hire: even so their offence is
not small ye suffer such as are faithfull
feeders of the flocke, to perish and decay
through need. For in another place the
Lord speketh to his disciples saying, Ye
have freely received it, and therefore
give it freely. But he speaketh of ye gift
of working miracles, & of the benefite
of health to be bestowed upon the sick,
diseased, and oppressed. For thus it is
written: Heale the sicke, cleanse the
leaprous, raise the dead, cast out de,
vils. And to these words he added this,
saying: Ye have received it freely, and
therefore bestowe it freely. Therefore
though ye Apostles received rewarde of
the to whom they preached: yet never
any man read that ever they tooke any
thing for the gift of healing which they
received in ye Lords name. Like as He
liseus would not take any thing at all
though it were freely offered him by
Naaman the Syrian captaine, for that
by his counsel he was healed of the le
prosie. Yet the self same Heliseus refu
sed not the gift of the man that came
unto him from Baal-salisa. Out of the
selfe same Gospell of Christ our Lord,
Ministers have to learne to what use
they ought to put ye wages they have
of the church. For what time the Lord
commaunded Judas who carried the
purse, to depart, the residue of the disci
ples thought that he had beene coman
ded to go and buy such necessaries as
should serue for the holy day, or else to
bestow something on the poore. There
fore it is plain that the Lord used with
ye stipend which he received, to provide
necessaries for him and his, and also
to give almes therof, Marke well then
that the ministers of the Church may
provide thinges necessarie for their li
ving, function, and maintenance of
their housholde, of the wages they re
ceive of the church. Againe, they may
also of the same wages give almes un
to the poore, even as it were of their
owne goods truly gotten. For the Lord
saith plainly in the law, that the sacri
fice of the Levites made of tythes, and
other oblations or holy revenves, shall
be as acceptable unto him, as their sa
crifice that offer any thing out of their
owne chest, store, or possessions. Truly
if a labourer doe offer unto God any
thing of his hire or wages (that is to
say) if he give unto the poore, doth it not
seeme a verie acceptable sacrifice unto
God: Very acceptable then is ye almes
that the minister of the church doth be
stowe, proceeding of the wages of the
holy ministerie. Put the case a labo
rer in building a church, receiveth his
wages of ye church goods, should a man
therfore say that the labourer tooke an
almes and y one almes ought not to be
given out of an other? He received wa
ges for his worke. For hee did labour.
Therefore he giveth almes of his wa
ges & of his own, lawful & proper goods.
Therefore then should the minister of
the church seeme to live by almes, and ye
he ought not to give almes of almes,
who notwithstanding doth labour for
his wages, & therfore receiveth the re
ward of his worke as a labourer doth,
unto whom the Lord himselfe compa
reth the minister: If any man be so far
past honestie to thinke so, he shal heare
not what I say, but what Paul the A
postle sayth. lf we sowe unto you spiri
tuall thinges, is it a great matter if we
mowe your carnal things? And againe,
Such elders as governe well, are wor
thie of double honor, and chiefly that
travell in preaching and teaching. For
the Scripture sayeth, Thou shalt not
mousell the mouth of the Oxe trea
ding out the corne. And The labou
rer is worthie of his hire. Beholde
therefore, the Apostle doth not thinke ye
that inestimable goodnesse of the mi
nisterie can by any meanes be recom
pensed with a vile thing, I mean with
earthly wages. Againe, They that la
boyr, saieth he: They that labour say
I, not they saith he, that loyter in tea
ching. These doeth hee compare unto
an ore that is a toyling beast, and a
thresher out of corne, & also to a labou
ring man. That whereof I do so greatly
warne you, is, that because in this our
wicked & unthankefull world, certaine
men, nay rather monsters most un
thankfull are to be found out, that are
perswaded, that ministers do nothing
at all, yea, even such as most faithfully
doe their duetie. For they cry out say
ing, They eate their bread as beggers
doe, and it costeth them nought. By
which name and infamie they terrifie
many fine wits, and make them to for
sake the studie of good learning & divi
nity, so that they utterly abhor the m
inistery, as it were a thing most begger
ly & unhonest. For in such fort the di
vel can decise to enlarge his kingdom,
abusing, or rather fitlie using to his
purpose our ingratitude & malice. But
why do they not suffer them selves to
be numbred with Christ and the holy A
postles, who were fed &maintained by
ned up among those unthakful & proud
people, who have scraped and gathered
all their goods together for the most
part, by usury & other wicked means: or
at ye least if they have not gotten their
goods by sinister meanes, they have re
ceived them through the liberalitie &
meere goodnesse of God, for the which
they never sweate or tooke paines?

S. Paule prooveth by strong and
many arguments the right to receive
a stipend for the holy ministerie. Have
we not (saieth he) power and auto
ritie to eate and drinke, or may we
not carrie about with us a woman
sister? for he meaneth the lawfulnesse
and authoritie to receive anie thing
necessarie for him selfe, his wife, and
his whole housholde. And for that
he asketh a question, he sheweth what
he meaneth, that thereby hee may de
clare a plaine trueth and equitie a
mongest all men, and thereto addeth
examples, not of every man senerally,
but of all generally, and specially of
the chiefest Apostles of Christ, and of
them that were kinne unto Christ by
bloude, saying: Even as the other A
postles and brothers of our Lorde,
and Cephas? And who is that Ce
phas, but Peter? To this Cephas the
Lorde saide in the first chapter of S.
John: Thou shalt be called Cephas,
which if a man interpret it, signifieth
a stone. But Peter also was so sir
named of a rocke, to the intent the in
terpretation of the name may alwaies
fall upon the same.

And who, I pray you are the Lords
brethren, but John and James, and
James the brother of Judas, and Ju
das & Simon the brethren of James:
All these, saith Saint Paule, lived of
the stipende they had, beeing gathe
red of the common assemhlie of the
Church. Unto these examples he ad
deth other also like unto them, com
monly put in practise. who (sayeth
hee) doeth goe to warre at his owne
costes and chargesy Or who planteth
a vineyearde, and eateth not of the
fruite thereof? Or who feedeth a
flocke and eateth not of the milke
there of? Surely hee bringeth foorth
these similitudes verie sinely and pro
perly applyed unto them, and not un
to anie other. For the ministers of
the Church are sometime called soul
diers or vineyard. keepers, sometime
husbandmen and shepeheardes. And
who I pray you, is so farre from rea
son : that he would denie unto souldi
ers hushandmen, & shepeheards meate
and clothing, for the paines they take
in warfare, husbandrie, and about cat
tell? The true hearted men therefore,
and such as are of an indifferent judg,
ment, do acknowledge that the mi
nisters of the Church may live by the
Ecclesiasticall ministerie. But least
that manie shoulde obiecte that these
humane parables and similitudes ta
ken from the common use, doe proove
nothing in an Ecclesiasticall cause,
hee addeth presently: Doe I speake,
these thinges according to man? Doth
not the lawe saye also the samer For
it is written in the lawe of Moses,
Thou shalt not mossell the Oxe that
treadeth out the corne. As though
hee should say, I have in a readinesse
for the confirmation of our right, not
onely humane similitudes, but also te
stimonies of the holy Scripture. And
he alledgeth a place out of the 2, chap,
of Deuteronomie, concerning the nou
rishing of labouring oxen. Againe,
least any man shoulde say that place
is not to be understoode of preachers,
but simplie of oxen, hee addeth, Doth
GOD take care for oxen? Or doth
not hee speake it altogether for our
sakes? Doubtlesse he hath written it
for our sakes, that he which ploweth
may plowe in hope, and he that thre
sheth in hope may be partaker of his
hope. The Lorde sayde, hee in his
lawe woulde provide for us. For hee,
would have the equalitie gathered by
a certaine sullogisme or kinde of
argument , after this or such like
manner: If the Lorde provided for
beastes and cattell, and would have
consideration to bee had of them, how
much more of men: It were truely a
verie unjust thing that an husbandma
shoulde labour with his oxe without
hope, that is to say in vaine, and with
out commoditie. Therefore were it
also a most unjust thing, for the mini
ster to exercise Ecclesiasticall husban
drie in the church without hope or due
stipend. Moreover, where it is againe
objected here against, that unto the spi
rituall ministery, belongeth no corpo
rall but a spiritual rewarde, the Apo
stle answeareth, lf wee sow unto you
spirituall thinges, is it a greate mat
ter if we reape your temporall things?
Hee therfore thinketh that the Corin
thians give nothing when they give
their temporall things, namely, if they
be compared with eternal good things,
which the ministers doe bring by tea
ching. For looke how farre the soule
excelleth the body, by so much more are
spirituall thinges better than tempo
rall. The Apostle also concealeth an
evident argument in these woordes,
where he admonisheth that it is meete
that hee that soweth should also reape.
In this point also is great inequality,
in that the ministers sowe the better,
and reape the woorse. Because men
set light by God and the divine mini
sterie, therefore they thinke that the
ministers doe nothing. S. Paule a
gaine confirmeth his own right by the
example of others, saying: If others
bee partakers of the power towardes
you, why rather are not wee? For
seeing none had taken more paines a
mong the Corinthians than S. Paul,
no man was more worthy of reward.
Moreover hee confirmeth his right,
by the example, commandement and
ordinaunce of the Lorde , saying :
Knowe yee not that they which take
paines in the holy thinges, doe eate
of the holy things, and they that mini
ster at the altar are partakers of the al
tar? Even so hath the Lord ordeyned,
that they that doe preach the Gospel,
should live of the Gospel. Where hath
the Lorde ordeyned this? Forsooth whe
he said in the Gospel, that the laborer
is worthy of his hire. But. I judge this
especially to be observed which the A
postle speaketh in plaine wordes, that
the Lord instituted his ordinance con
cerning the maintenance of the mini
sters of the church unto the imitation
of the auncient lawes of the Jewish
people. Hereof we gather, ye we misse
not much the marke, if in this & suche
like cases wee doe not utterly reiect the
aunctient institutions of the fathers.

But in that S. Paul the Apostle
used not his authoritie as hee might
have done, it maketh nothing against
these thinges. For one question is of
the deede, and another of the right of ye,
thing. In very deede, hee tooke no
thing of the Corinthians for diverse
causes, yet not withstanding he took of
other Churches. Neither received hee
any thing of the Church of Thessalo
nica : yet for al that this doing is not
prejudiciall to the equity of the right
For he saith unto the Corinthians: I
have robbed other churches, having
received wages of them, to the intent
I might doe you service. And when
I was with you and wanted, I was
not burthensome unto any man. For
the thinges that were lacking unto
mee, were given mee by the brethren
that came from Macedonia. And un
to the Thessalonians he saith, We be
haved not our selves inordinately a
mongst you, neither did wee take our
bread for nothing. But with labour
and payne both night and day, doing
our worke, to the intent wee woulde
not be a burden unto any of you. Not
that it is not lawfull for us to doe it,
but because we woulde set downe our
selves as a patterne for you to follow
after. And agayne the same S. Paul
saieth unto the Thessalonians, I be
seeche you that you acknowledge the
that labour among you, and are over
you in the Lorde, and admonish you,
that you have them in singular love
through love for their worke sake. Be
at peace with them. Let so much ther
fore of the church goods as is sufficient
be given unto the ministers & teachers,
so farre forth as honest necessity requi
reth. And thus much have we spoken
concerning the proportion that is due
unto pastors.

In times past the seconde parte of
ecclesiasticall goods was allotted unto
clearkes. And clearkes are the harvest
of Pastors, studious of divinity , and
wholly disposed to the holy ministery.
And forasmuch as these have dedica
ted theselves and all that they have
wholly to the Church & the ministerie
thereof, it is most fit that they shoulde
be nourished & mainteined by the costs
of the Church. But it is convenient
they be nourished meanly, who ought
to be an example of meave and thrifty
living to other.

For to bee brought up delicately,
doth nothing agree with the ministe
ries of the Church. And therefore, A
mos founde fault that the Nazarites
dranke wine, for that he meant that
drunkardes did not mainteine the
church, but utterly destroy it. Of which
matter wee spake in another place,
Moreover, it is fit that due portions be
payde to Priests, schoolemaisters, scho
lers, and to all other ecclesiasticall per
sons whatsoever.

Finally the third part of ecclesiasti
call goodes are appoynted for the poore,
And there are divers fortes of poore
folke: as widowes, pupils, orphanes, &
infantes cast out (whose parentes are
not known. Also they that are worne
with old age, and spent with diseases,
There are insinite kindes of diseases,
whereof the most grievous are these:
leprosie, furie, and madnes, the french
pockes, or the scabbe of India or Na
ples, the palsey, the goute, and a great
many moe. Ther are not onely poore
men borne within the lande, but also
straungers that are banished their
countrey and home for righteousnesse
sake, and for the worde of God. There
are other who are not yet come to ex
treme poverty, but are even now rea
dy to fall into it, so that if they be not
holpen a litle with ready money, they
by & by come to be kept by the church
bore. Againe, there are some that are
consumed by imprisonmet, by warres,
by great Clouds of waters, by fire, and
divers other mishappes, as by hayle,
frostes, & other stormes and distempe
ratures of the ayre.

Of all whose health and safegard
the Lorde willed us to bee mindeful,
whereas hee saith, that whatsoever
wee bestowe uppon the poore, wee
bestowe it uppon him. Therefore if
wee despise and regarde not the poore,
without al doubt wee despise and neg
lect even our Lorde God himelfe in
the poore. Wee ought of duety to suc
cour the poore of our owne good will,
by counsell, comfort, medicines, cures,
money, meate, drink, clothes, lodging.
succouring, and by anye meanes else
that wee may, and in all such matters
and cases, as they sh all have neede of
our helpe. It so bee the Church goodes
are not sufficient to performe all this
at the full, then let the aboundance of
all other good faithfull people supplye
their want. But if there bee goods suf
ficient in store laid up, which have byn
in times past cotributed by the libera
lity of the godly, which notwithstading
through negligence or wickednes of
governors are taken away, so that the
necessity of the poore cannot thereby be
succoured, for that cause truely moste
shary tempests of infelicities are pow
red forth both upon common wealths
and kingdomes.

For why, they are very sharply pu
nished which do not give unto ye poore
of their owne private goods if they bee
able: with how much more grievous
calamities may wee think they shalbe
plagued, which wickedly, sacrilegious
ly & forcibly take away to their owne
private uses, those riches which were
given by others to the common use of
the poore? Hee that hath this worlds
substance and seeth his brother want,
and shutteth up his affectio from him,
is cruell : therfore he that taketh from
the poore that which is already given
them is more cruel, and committeth sa
criledge.

It is read that the Sodomites with
their fellow cities were burned, be
cause they strengthened not the hand
of ye poore but rather weakened it. The
Moabits & Chanaanites are destroied
for disdaining straungers, & for having
no care of the poore. But why do wee
fetch examples so farre off? why do we
not call to mind the last sentence of the
high Judge uttered from his heaven
ly judgement seate which is stablished
in the cloudes, pronounced in this
manner, Come ye blessed of my fa
ther, possesse the kingdome which
was prepared for you from the begin
ning of the world. I have byn hungry
and you have given me meat. I have
byn a thirsty and you have given me
drinke. I was a straunger and you har
boured me, l was naked and you clo
thed me, I was sick, & you visited me.
I was in prison, & you came unto me.
The evangelist also addeth that which
agreeth verye muche to our purpose:
Then shall the just aunsweare and say,
Lord, when saw we thee hungry and
gave thee meate: thirsly & gave thee
drinke: when saw we thee harbour,
lesse and lodged thee : or naked and
cloathed thee? Or when saw we thee
sick or in prison, & came unto thee?
The king aunswearing, shall say unto
them, Verily l say unt o you, in that
you did it unto one of the least of
these my brethren, you did it unto
me. Then shal he say also unto them
that are on his lese hand, Depart from
me ye cursed, into everlasting fire,
which is prepared for the divel and his
Angels. For I was hungry, and you
gave me no meate. I was thirsty and
you gave me no drinke, I was a straun
ger and you harboured me not. I was
naked & you cloathed me not. I was
sick and in prison, and you visited me
not. Then shal they answere & say un
to him, Lord, when saw we thee hun
gry, or thirsty, or a straunger, or na
ked, or sick, or in prison, & ministred.
not unto thee? Then shall he answere
them, saying: Verily l say unto you,
in as much as you did it not unto one
of the least of these, neither did you
it unto me. It foloweth after, And they
shal goe into everlasting punishment,
but the righteous into everlasting
life. The Lord also in an other place in
the Gospell substituting the poore in
his steed, saith: Ye have the poore with
you alwaies, & when ye wil ye may do
them good: but me ye shal not have al
waies. And therfore we reade that the
Primitive Church was careful in pro
viding for the poore, even to the woor
king of miracles.

S. Paul in all places commendeth
the poore to the Church of GOD: hee
made collections for the poore almost in
al Churches, and the blessings: which
hee had gathered, hee distributed with
great judgement, faith and diligence.
As it will appeare almost in all his e
pistles, specially in the 15. to the Ro
maines, in the first to the Corinthians
the sirteenth Chapter, in the second to
the Corinthians the eight and ninth
Chapters. And to the Galathians,
While wee have time (saith hee) let us
doe good towardes all men, especial
ly towardes the housholde of faith. In
the first Epistle to Timothie, hee war
neth that there bee consideration had
who should be holpen, and who not to
be holpen. In ye same Epistle he giveth
charge to Timothie, and to al the Bi
shops how to deale with the richer fort
in the Church saying: Commaunde
them that are rich in this worlde, that
they be not high minded, neither put
their trust in uncertaine riches, but in
the living GOD, who giveth us all
things abundantly to enjoy, that they
may doe good, that they may bee rich
in good workes, that they may be rea
die to give and bestow willingly, lay
ing up unto theselves a good fouda
tio against the time to come, that they
may take holde of life everlasting. And
unto the Hebrewes, To do good et to
distribute forget not: for with such sa
crifice God is pleased.

Wherefore, riches were gathered even
in the time of the Apostles to succour
ye necessity of the poore withal. Deacos
were appointed by the Church as pro
viders and stewardes: among whom
those first Deacons were moste fa
mous, of whom the Actes of the Apo
stles make mention, and also the no
table martyr of Christ Laurence. And
the writings of the ancient fathers do
testifie that with those ecclesiasticall
goods, prisoners were redeemed out of
captivity, poore maides of lawful yeres
married, finally hospitals, almeries,
spittels, harbours, hostles, and nourse
ries were builded, namely to entertain
poore travellers, for the maintenaunce
of the poore that were born in that cou
trie, for the reliefe of the sicke and dis
eased, for the necessitie of old men, and
for the honest bringing up of puplis &
orphans. Concerning these matters
there are yet extant certaine imperial
lawes.

Wherefore in reforming of Chur
ches, very diligent heede must be take
that there be no offence committed in
this behalf through oversight or of pur
pose, that the poore be not defrauded, &
that in taking away ons abuse, wee
bring not in many.

If there be plenty of goods, let them
be kept: if there be none, let the be ga
thered of the rich. The let the state of
the poore be searched, and what every
man needeth most, or howe provision
may best be made for every one. which
being knowne, let that which is meete
and necessary for every one bee done
speedily, gently, & diligently. If then
any of the common goods remaine, let
them be kept against such calamities
as may ensue. Let nothing bee consu
med unprofitably or ungodlily.

Again, let not the treasure of the poore
unhappily be detained from them by
fraude, and to the increasing of their
povertie, For there may bee like of
fence commited on both sides. For
on eche side the poor are defrauded of
their goods. Touching liberalitie, wee
have intreated in an other place in
these our Decades : and of providing
for the poore, in other of our woorkes.
And Lewis Viues hath written very
wel of releeving the poore.

The fourth and last part of the
goods of the Church, apperteineth un
to holy buildings, as churches, scholes,
and houses belonging to churches, and
schooles. Churches which because of
the companies gathered together in
them are also called cogregations, are
the houses of the Lorde our God. Not
that God whom the wide compasse of
the heavens cannot comprehend, doth
dwell in suche manner of houses, but
because the congregation and people
of GOD meet together in those hou
ses, to worship and performe due ho
nour unto God, to heare the worde of
God, to receive the Lords sacraments,
and to pray for the assistance and pre
sence of God. Churches therefor are
very necessary for the Church & people
of God. Touching holy assemblies, I
have said somewhat in the disputati
ons of prayer.

And although that at the comman
demet of God, Moses builded a move
able Churche, and afterward the most
wise king Solomon founded a stan
ding Church not without great cost,
notwithstanding we must not thinke
therfore that God liketh of such great
chareges after that he had sent Christ,
and fulfilled the figures. For as before
the law was made, it is not to be foud
that the Patriarches did ever build a
ny Minsters and great Churches, e
ven so after the disanulling of the law
in the Church of Christ, a meane and
sparing cleanlines pleaseth God best,
For God misliketh that foolish & mad
kinde of buildinges, not much unlike
to that unwise building of Babylon,
enterprising to set up the toppe of the
tower above the cloudes. For God li
keth not the riotousnesse of Churches,
who without all riot doth gather his
church together from out all the parts
of the worlde, which Church also hee
hath taught both sparingnesse and the
contempt of al riot. A Church is large
and bigge enough, it it be sufficient to
receive al that belong unto it. For the
place is provided for men and not for
God. But above all thinges let that
place be cleane and holy. A Church is
hallowed or consecrated, not (as some
doe superstitiously thinke) with the re
hearsing of certeyne wordes or ma
king signes and Characters, or with
oyle, or purging fire, but with the wil
of God and his commandement, bid
ding us to assemble and come together,
promising his presence amongst us : &
also, it is allowed by the holy use of it.
For in the temple the holy Churche of
God is gathered together:the true and
most blessed word of God is also decla
red in the temple: the holy Sacramets
of God are received in the temple: and
also in the temple prayers are powred
foorth to God which are most accepta
ble unto him.

Verily the place of it selfe is no
thing holy, but because these holy,
things are done in that place in respect
that they are done there, the place it
selfe is called holy. Therefore not with
out great cause ought all prophanati
on and filthines be farre from the holy
temple of the Lorde. The Senatours
court or seat of judgemet is accounted
so holy a thing, that whosoever either
in word or deedeused himselfe unreve
rently towardes it, should be accused
of treason. And yet in this court the
Senators onely are gathered and as
sembled together, to heare the matters
of suiters in thinges transitory that
shall passe away and perish. By how
much the more then ought reverence
to bee given unto temples, into the
which the children of God doe come to
woorship him, to heare the true word
of God, and to receive his holy sacra
ments: And therefore as we hate and
abandon all superstition in temples,
so we love not the prophanation of
them, yea rather I say wee can not
abide it. Neither have wee leysure at
this time about the consideration of
temples to rehearse and search out of
pen and plaine superstitios. Of which
matter wee have spoken in another
place.

I finde it a matter of controversie
amog the fathers of old time, to what
part of the worlde we ought to turne
when we pray. Socrates the historio
grapher in his fifth booke cap.2a, spea
king of the most, aunctient Apostolique
Church of the whole worlde at. Anti
oche, saith: At Antioche, which is
in Syria, the Churche is set contrarie
to other, for the altar, looketh not ro
wards the East, but towards the West.
It may bee they, did imitate, the fa
shion of the old people in building and
setting their tabernacle, and in the fa
shion of their temple. For they woor
shipped God turning towardes the
West, without doubt because of the
comming of Christ in the latter time,
and at the ende of the worlde. Other
wise it is comonly used that men wor
ship with their faces toward the East,
But in al these matters so there be no
superstition, dissention, licentiousnes
and offence, a man may doe what him
lusteth.

But there ought no temple to bee
built for the worshipping of saintes,
For unto God onely, to whom all ho
nour and worship is due, we ought to
build Churches: which thing we are
taught by the examples of ancient fa
thers, and the determination of the
whole scripture. The heathenish ido
laters built temples unto creatures,
sinning against the true and eternall
God in committing a grievous offece,
S. Augustine in his booke, De civita
te Dei, saith plainely. We builde not
temples unto our Martyres. And again
in his first booke against Maximinus
a bishoppe of the Arians, If we should
(saith he) builde a Church of timber
and stones unto some excellent holye
Angel, should we not bee accursed by
the truth of Christ, and the Church of
God? Because we should do that ser
vice unto a cteature, that is due onely
to God? Therefore if we should com
mit sacriledge in making a temple, to
every creature whatsoever, how may
it be that God is not true unto, whom
we make no temple, but we our selves
are actemple for him? Thus much sai
eth he. Againe, they are to be counted
lyars, wo affirm ye temples were built
by certaine religious men in the woor
ship of the apostles while they were a
live. Of which matter we have spoke,
in times past, as we have both against
the riotousnes of the Church, & the un
profitable expenses there of, in the first
booke intituled, De origine erroris, the
23. chap.

Instrumentes belonging to the
church, ought to be holy, cleane, and
voyde of all riot, and farre from any
kinde of superstition. The instru
ments be these, an holy seate or pul
pit, in the which the minister maye,
teach and preache : convenient seates
for the congregation: a Font readye
to baptise infants in, and the Lords
Table, with such thinges as are ne
cessary thereto, as water, bread, wine,
bookes, candles, baskets, and cuppes.
These at some times were all of gold:
but good and godly Bishoppes have
often times molten them, and there
withall delivered prisoners out of cap
tivity, and fedde such as were like to
perish for hunger. Many examples of
this fort have I gathered in my booke
of the Institution of Bishoppes, the 9.
Chapter. As for candles, whereof wee
made mention even nowe, sure it is
that the ancient fathers used them in
the Churches to drive away the dark
nes of the night, as it appeareth in the
twentie Chapter of the Actes of the A
postles. But it is, a foolish matter and
nothing religious to use lightes in the
worshipping of God, Lactantius crieth
out, shal we judge him to be wel in his
wits which offereth the light of a bur
ning wato, candle or taper for a pre
sent to the authour and giver of light?
Hee requireth other manner of light
at our handes, and that not smoakie,
but cleare and bright, to wit the light
of the minde. But a man may com
monly see in these dayes, a great part
of the worshipping of God to be repo
sed in the offering of candels, which
thing is cleane against the manifest
truth.

Amongst other instruments of the
Church, bels are reckoned uppe, which
at these dayes are unto us, as in olde
time trumpets were unto the people of
God For they serve to cal the congre
gatio together, and they are numbred
among tokens and warnings. About
bels there is a wonderful superstition.
They are christened by bishops: and it
is thought ye they have power to put
away any great tempest. In the olde
time men were stirred up to prayer by
the ringing of them, what time any
fore tempest did rise: but now the very
ringing of bels, by reason of their cose
cratio seemeth to have a peculiar kind
of vertue in it. Who can but marvel
and be astonied at this extreme blind
nesse? Moreover they use belles to be
wayle the dead. Al which things are
superstitious, and , utterly to bee con
temned.

For so much as the true use of the
church goods consisteth in those things
which we reckoned up before, it follo
weth that the abuse therof must needs
be in the rotraries, whether we do of
fend in one kind or in many. Justice &
equity is to be kept in these as well as
in all other things.

We ought not to take from one ma
& give to another, but wee must give
unto every one that which is his own.
Therefore we may not take any thing
from the poore and give it to the mini
sters of ye church : neither is their por
tion and necessaries to be taken from
them, that the poore may live thereof.
The holy scripture giveth one portion
of the church goods to the ministers of
the Church : and the same Churche
willeth us to give unto the poore their
part. Therefore if bishops or ministers
of the Church do challenge unto them
selves all the church goods, & give not
unto the poore their partes due unto
them, they defile themselves with sa
criledge.

If the ministers do not challege un
to theselves al the goods of the Church,
& yet doe take unjustly more than ey
ther it becommeth them, or than neede
requireth, or otherwise than the decree
of God and the Apostles doth allowe:
or else if they spende unthriftily that
portion due unto the, they grievously
offende. But they sinne greatly, yea,
most horribly if they wast the goodes
of the poore, in hunting, dicing, drin
king and ryoting, whore hunting, or
else in warrefare, and in the meane
time: have no regarde of the Church,
neyther care whut is done there, or
how.

But if a just and good portion fall
unto the poore, perhaps there will bee
a fault in this poynt, in the Steward
or Almonar through favour or ha
tred, that they that have most neede
shall have nothing, and the least wor
thie shall have most, then in this case
there is also great offence committed
through filthy abuse. But of all abu
ses, that seemeth to be the shamefullest
which is nowe a daies almost com
monly used. Wee bestow great costes
and chareges upon stones and stockes,
that is to say uppon idols voyde of all
understanding: but there is no regard
had unto the poore who are the perfect
images of God. Which kinde of mad
nes is heathenish & extreme folly. But
forsomuch as other have already very,
largely spoke of the abuse of the church
goods, & we also have set down certain,
matters concerning the same else
where, I will for this time make an
end of speaking thereof.

I would also now intreate of the ho
ly time, which treatise is altogether
like that of the holy place, whereof we
disputed elsewhere, but that we have
also discoursed therof in the expouiding
of the tenne commaundements. This,
onely I doe adde at this present time,
that there ought to bee no odious con
tention in the church concerning that
matter, but that in this and other such
like cases, discipline with charitie is
constantly to bee observed. For it be
houeth us to bee mindfull of the most
pernicious contention about the kee
ping of Easter, which with much dan
ger and great detriment, much and
long time troubled the churches of the
East and West: and beware in anye
case that through contention there bee
not a gappe left open unto Sathan to
enter in. It were profitable in mine
opinion both in this case and in suche
like, to remember the counsell which
S. Augustine giveth, That that which
is enjoyned us, and is neither against
faith, nor good manners, is to be ac
counted indifferent, and to be obser
ved according to the societie of them
with whom we live. In the 118. Epi
stle to Januarius.

Unto the holy ministery belongeth
also discipline and correction of the
ministers. How necessary this is, it
may bee gathered by these woordes of
our Lorde Christ, You are the salt of
the earth. If the salt hath lost her salt
nesse, what shall bee salted therewith?
It is good for nothing else but to bee
thrown out of the doores, & to be tro
den uuder foote of men. I know there
bee some that doe boast them selves of
certaine priviledges wherby they are
exempted from all discipline. But
they are deceived for the Lorde hath
made all the ministers of his Church
subject unto discipline. Tho so ther
fore will bee exempted from discipline.
are not Christes ministers, Or, who I
pray you will say that hee is free from
discipline, whom the Lord would have
altogether subject and bounde unto it?
Against the commaundement of God
there is no Popes lawe, no priviledge
of king or Emperour of force. For no
man can abrogate the decree of the
high God. And the Lord commandeth
to warne and correct every brother
that doth amisse : therefore would hee
have us also sharpely to admonishe
the ministers of the churches that are
negligent and go astray. Truely he
himselfe did often and very sharpely
reprove the whole order of the Priests
of the church of Hierusalem. Helie the
Lords priest is ill reported of in ye holie
Scripture for that hee brideled not his
sonnes beeing Priestes, with sharper
discipline. Wee reade howe the pro
phets of the Lord blamed very bitter
ly all the Colledges of Priests, and the
high Priests also. Examples are to bee
founde in every place throughout the
holy history, and in the writings of the
Prophets. Yea, Saynt Paul repro
ved the most holy Apostle saint Pe
ter at Antioch in Syria in the sight of
the whole Congregation, for that hee
taught not directly according to ye pre
script rule of the Gospell. And to bee
short, Christ himself in the revelation
which was made to S. John the Apo
stle, doth very sharply admonish and
reprove the Angels, that is to say, the
Ministers of the Churches. Again,
Saint Paul the Apostle sayth, Against
an Elder, receive no accusation, but
under two or three witnesses. But
those that doe offende reprove before
the whole Congregation, that the o
ther may stand in feare. There are ex
tant also in the scriptures many nota
ble examples of most holy princes, who
by their lawes have restrained even
the chiefest ministers of the Churches,
and have thrust downe from their
chaires & degrees such as did not well
dicharge their dueties. Yea verie ne
cessitie it self, and the good estate of the
people of God requireth, ye the naugh
tie Ministers of Churches be deposed.
And better it were that a few evil mi
nisters were troubled, than so manie
Congretations brought into daunger
of bodie and soule. For the Churches
and congregations are utterly destroi
ed, through the negligence and ungod
linesse of wicked Pastours. Therefore
let them be deposed with speede. But to
the ende that the Ministers of Chur
ches, might the better and the more ea
silie be kept in their function and cal
ling, the ancient fathers in the old time
solemnely helde Convocations of the
Cleargie once or twice in a yeare, ap
plying the same as remedies to the
diseases of the Minsiters. And that I
may not bring any thing here farre set
I will recite unto you (deerly beloved)
what is read in the Imperial constitu
tions of the Emperor Justinian com
maunding after this manner: The an
cient Fathers solemnely helde Convo
cations twice a yeare,
in everie Province, that such thinges
as are growen up, may there be exa
mined, and amended by competent
correction. Which hetherto not bee
ing observed, it seemeth nowe to bee
needefull, to bring it to right way.
And forasmuch as wee our selves by
reason of this negligence have founde
manie to bee intrapped with sundrie
errors and sinnes, we commaund them
all, that in all provinces everie yeare,
either in the monethes of July or Sep
tember one Synode bee holden, and
that the Priests meete together, either
at the Patriarches or the Bishops, and
that there matters of faith bee hand
led, and also of CAnonicall questions,
and of the administration of Eccle
siasticall thinges, or of reproveable
life, or other matters which require
correction. These thinges being thus
observed, the laitie also shall reape
much profit concerning the true faith
and honest life, and amendement of
themselves to the better. Immediate
ly after he addeth these wordes: More
over, we cammaund the lieutenants
of the provinces, if they see this to
be negligently looked unto, that they
urge the BIshops to assemble Synodes.
But if they perceive them to seeke
delayes, and to be negligent heerein,
let them certifie us thereof, that wee
may proceede with due correction a
gainst such lingerers. Thus much
have I reported out of the Caesarial de
cree. Therefore let Bishops take heede,
that in his behalfe there be no fault
committed through their negligence:
and if they forget their duetie, let the
magistrate beware that he winke not
at their sluggishnes, to the destruction
of the whole Church, and all the Mini
sters of Christ. There creepe in conti
nually many vices, for that the disposi
tion of the sieth is verie corrupt. Unles
therefore there bae admonition in the
Church, and correction continually put
in use, those things which we thinke to
bee most firme, shall fall to decay and
perish sooner than we suppose. Like as
the Lord would have the transgressing
ministers of the Churches, privately
to be admonished and correded, so doth
he extende the commoditie of the same
admonition & correction to the whole
Church. And therefore the auncient
church had an holy Senate of Elders,
which diligently warned them that
transgressed in the Church, corrected
them sharpely, yea, and excluded them
out of the Ecclesiasticall fellowshippe,
namely if they perceived, that there
was no hope of amendment to bee loo
ked for in them. But in ye latter times,
the Popes and Bishops tyrannically
taking that kinde of punishment into
their handes, and exercising it sacrile
giously contrary to the first institution
have touched an wholesome medicine
into an hurtfull poyson, making it ab
hominable both to the good and bad.
Saint Paul teaching that this kinde
of punishment was permitted by the
Lord to restraine the licentiousnesse of
manie, sayth, I have decreed, that he
which hath committed this offence,
when you bee gathered together, in
the name of our Lord Jesus Christ and
my spirite with you, together with the
power of our Lorde Jesus Christ, be
delivered to sathan to the destruction
of the flesh, that the spirite may be sa
ved in the day of the Lorde Jesus. Lo,
this is the power and revengement of
the Elders of the church. The meanes
is, the destruction of the flesh. The end
is, the saftie of the spirit, or the saving
of a faithfull man. For the same Apo
stle to the Theff. hath these wordes, If
there be anie man, saith he, that obey
eth not our wordes, signifie to mee of
him by an Epistle, and see that ye have
nothing to doe with him, that he may
be ashamed: neyther will I you to ac
count him as an enemie, but warne
him as a brother. The same Apostle
also plainly shewing in an other place,
who ought to be punished by the Ec
clesiastical sword, not such as be offen
ders, through weaknesse of the flesh, or
good men, being adjudged for heretikes
of the Bishops onely or their company
about them, or poore men for not pay
ing their duetie to their Ordinarie or
their Official, but wicked dooers, and
pernicious men. If anie man sayth he,
that is called a brother, be a whore
hunter, or a covetous person, or an
Idolater, or a flaunderer, or a drun
karde, or a theefe, with such see that
ye eate not. S. Augustine doth admit
moderation in giving punishment, and
then especially, when through punish
ment, not the edifying but the destra
ction of the Church is to bee feared.
Which feare might perhaps seeme, ey
ther vaine, or else too much, if the same
Apostle who commandeth the incestu
ous adulterer to be delivered to satan,
had not said in the latter Ep. to ye Cor.
I feare that when I come I shall not
finde you such ones as I would, and
shall mourne for manic that offended
before, and have not repented them
selves of their uncleannesse, and of
their whoring and wantonnesse they
have used, & c. Truely he threateneth
them hardly that he will not spare the:
but because he perceived that it did ra
ther tende to the bitter destruction and
over-throwe of the Church, than to
the gathering together and increase
thereof, if (as he did the adulterer) he
should deliver them unto Sathan, hee
used moderation therein according to
Gods commandement, Suffer both of
the to grow, leaft that while ye plucke
uppe the cockle, ye also pull uppe the
wheate by the rootes. It is necessarie
therefore that holy judgement be used,
least offence be committed either by too
much favour, or by too much extremi
tie. Moreover, let speedie reconciliati
on be of force among such as be repen
taunt. S. Paul saith, It is sufficient
to sucha a man, that hee bee thus bla
med or chidden. S. Peter who shame
fully denied the Lorde, doth heare of
women in the day of the resurrection,
the Gospel preached by Angels. More
over, wee have shewed that there is a
magistrate in the church, and autho
rity to execute the sword upon evil do
ers, and a magistrate which doth judge
and exercise the sworde, and not with
standing is reckoned up among ye true
members of the Church, yea, and that
a magistrate is very necessary for the
Church in respect of his office, as it is
set downe in our 7. and 8. Sermon of
the second Decade.

The speciall institutions and ordi
nances which God hath appointed in
the Church, are these that follow. And
truely amongst all the ordinaunces of
the Church, welocke is not to bee ac
counted least, which if it be well bled,
it bringeth foorth a great company of
good fruits in ye church, but if it be not
well ordered, it breedeth a number of
offences and deadly mischiefs in the
Churche. For they judge uprightly
which say, that that Churche is most
holy & best assembled, which is gathe
red together from out of many houses
well ordered: again, out of many wic
ked houses, a wicked Church is assem
bled. God therefore in his holy worde,
doth diligently appoynt couples, and
garnisheth wedlock very beautifully.
But it is not our purpose at this pre
sent to let forth the praise of matrimo
ny. For it sufficeth to know that God
himselfe is the authour of wedlocke, &
that he instituted it first in Paradise:
and hee did it to this ende, that man
might live wel & pleasantly with a fel
low: to conclude, he first couple the,
man and woman together, and being
coupled he blessed them: and that the
most holy friendes of God, the Patri
archs, Princes, Prophets, Kings, Bi
shops, wise men and Priests, lived in
this kinde of life. Wereof perhaps
S. Paul said, Wedlocke is honour
able amongst all men, and the bed un
defiled. He in another place calleth the
doctrine that forbiddeth wedlocke, The
doctrine of divelles. For it is evident
ly known, that Christs Disciples and
the Apostles were married men, ney
ther did they put away their wines,
when they took upon them the office of
preaching, though some most shame
fully feigne that they did.

It is not able that ye Apostle requi
reth at the hands of a bishop or an El
der to be the husband of one wife: and
that in another place he plainly saith,
that it is lawful to carry about a Chri
stian wife, being in the calling of the
Apostleship: and he challengeth it both to
himselfe & also to Barnabas. What
shall I say moreover that it was pro
nounced in the Councell of Nice, to
wit, that to lie with a mans own wife
is Charitie. For Saynt Paul had
said before, Let everie man have his
owne wife to avoyde fornication. And
The bed of wedlocke is undefiled. A
gaine, If a Virgin marrie, thee often
deth not. Wherefore we judge, that
Papisticall doctrine which forbiddeth
marriage unto ministers, to be such as
the blessed Apostle Saint Paul tear
med to be the doctrine of divelles. The
very Papists themselves, who have
not as yet put all shamefallnesse away,
will confesse it with us.

For if we judge the tree by the fruits,
I pray you what fruites of single life
may we recite? What filthines, what
bawdery, what adulteries, what forni
catios, what ravishings, what incests
and heinous copulations may wee re
hearse? Who at this bay liveth more
unchaste or dishonest, than the rabble
of Priests and Mokes doe? For as
they have no care or regarde to obeye
Gods word and his lawes, and to glo
rifie God with their holy life in chaste
wedlocke: even to hath God though
the desire of their hearts, given them
up unto all uncleannesse, that their bo
dies may be stained with reproch.

But first of all, the holie Scripture
diligently tearheth all men to have a
speciall care that they contract matri
monoie devoutly, holily, soberly, wisely,
lawfully, and in the feare of God, and
that no evil disposition of covetous
nesse, desire of promotion, or fleshlie
lust may leade and provoke them,
and that wedlocke be not entred into,
otherwise than eyther the Lawes of
man of God will permit.

And in this place we must consider
of the degrees of consanguinitie and
affinitie, of publique honestie, of the
reverence of bloud, of offence towards
other, and that no man take unto wife
a heathen woman, or one taht is of a
contrarie religion. For wee are ex
pressely forbidden to yeake our selves
with the unbeleevers.

Againe, we are taught to enter into
the knot of wedlocke lawfully, godily
and holily, with a prayer and the receipt
of godly blessing in the Temple of the
Lorde, both in the fight, and with the
prayer of the whole congregation: and
to beware that in anie case wee be not
stained in this point with all propha
nation of the filthie worlde.

Neither be we ignorant in this safe
also, that men of this worlde are com
monlie wont to celebrate their wed
dinges more fitte for the Divell shall
God, with rioting, pride, surfetting,
dronkennesse, and all kind of wan
tonnesse.

Moreover wee are taught to dwell
with our wives according to know
ledge, moderation, patience, faith, and
love, and also to bring hope our chil
dren certuously and honestly, and them
also to place and bestowe when time
requireth in holy wedlocke. But if for
adulterie, or some other matter more
heinous than that, necessitie forceth to
breake wedlocke, yet in this case the
Church will doe nothing unadvisedly.
For she hath her Judges, who will
judge in matters and causes of matri
monie according to right and equitie,
or rather according to Gods lawes,
and the rule of honestie. The holy Apo
stle would not have the faithfull to
contende and stande in Lawe in the
Court of the unfaithfull, wherefore
hee exhorteth them to take umpiers to
make agreementes friendly betweixt
them that were in contention.

But in causes and matters of ma
trimonie there are farre greater mat
ters that forbidde the parties that sue
or bee sued to come beore unbeleeving
Judges: Therefore the Church of God
hath verie well appointed a Court to
trie matters of matrimonie.

But because we spake of wedlock in
the tenth sermo of the second Decade,
and also have set forth somtime a booke
especially concerning the same I have
knit up this matter in these few words
touching Christian wedlocke.

The Church of God hath widowes
in it, but such, as the Apostle of Christ
doth describe in this fort, saying: Shee
that is a widowe and alone woman in
deede, trusteth in God, and continu
eth in prayer and supplication night
and day. But the that liveth in plea
sures and delightes, is dead though
thee be alive. The same Paule doth
will the younger sort to marrie to get
children, and to governe the house, nei
ther to give any occasion at al, for the e
nimie to speake evill of them: the place
is evident in the first epistle of S. Paul
to Timothie, the fift chap. The church
also hath virgins. There be careful on
ly for those things that long unto the
Lord and are true virgins without al
deceit or hypocrise.

Paul saith, A virgine careth for that
that belongeth to God, that thee may
be holy both in body and spirit. There
are many that rule and governe their
bodies, but not their minds: GOD re
quireth both, & specially of the mind.
It is an easie matter to deceive men,
but we cannot by anie means deceive
God. S. Paul in the first Epistle to the
Cor. the 7. cap., setteth forth the praise
of virginitie, & by comparing a virgin
to a married wife, bee sheweth howe
great the goodnesse of virginitie is.

Notwithstanding it is lawfull for
virgins to marrie if they will, which
thing the same Apostle plainely shew
eth in the selfe same place of Scip
ture. Unto this testimonie of God the
testimonie of man also is agreeable.
For Cyprian with his fellow Bishops
and Elders, making aniwere to a que
stion demaunded by Pomponius, saith,
Doest thou desire ye wee should write
unto thee what we thinke of those vir
gins, who after that they once determi
ned to continue their state coutinently
and steadfastly, are found to have lien
and continued in the same bedde with
men? concerning which thing because
thou doest desire to knowe our judge
ment, thou shalt understand, that wee
do not depart from the traditions and
ordinaunces of the Gospel and the A
postles, whereby we should so much
the lesse strongly and stoutly provide
for our brethren and sitters, and that
ecclesiasticall discipline shoulde bee
kept by all meanes, for their profite
and safetie. And it followeth, But if
through faith they have vowed unto
Christ, and continue chastly and sham
saitly without leafing, let them sted
fastly and stoutely looke for the re
warde of virginitie: But if they will not
or cannot continue, it is better that
they marrie, than to fall into the fire
of their delights and pleasures And
so forth. Saint Augustine disputing of
the wordes of the Apostle, having the
greater damnation, because they brake
their first promise and saith, ascri
beth not this damnation to the mar
riage following, but to the inconstan
cie going before. Such are damned
(saith he,) not because they entred in
to the bonde and promise of wedlock,
but because they brake the first pro
mise made of continencie and chasti
tie. And a little after that hee addeth
these wordes, They therefore that say
such marriages are no marriages in
deed, but rather adulteries, it seemeth
to mee that they speake foolishly and
without consideration. And this much
hee. I understande that by this worde
Condemnation or Judgement, is meant
by the Apostle Reprehension which
we Switzers terme, Ein anszicten
ordernachred. For they be evil spoken
of by many, for that they have broken
their first saith, that is to say, they
have broken the promise of continen
cie. Wherefore the Apostle thinketh
it much better, for young women to
matche them selves in marriage, than
to let downe to them selves such an
order of life, from the which although
necessitie forceth them thereunto, they
cannot depart without reprehension
of men. But in that place hee speaketh
not of virgins but of widowes. Saint
Cyprian speaketh simplie of virgins.

Monkes and Nonnes were alto
gether unknowne in the primitive
Church of Christ and the Apostles,
the latter ages had monkes, but not
such as are nowe a dayes, which are
their owne rule and alwe, whose mo
nasteries abound in all filthinesse and
uncleannes. Which though we should
hold our peace, yet to bee true, truth
it selfe and experience will sufficiently
declare. And those that seeme to be go
verned by more severe discipline are
defiled with hypocrisie, I will say none
other thing. Touching the first moks,
they dwelt not in cities, neither inter
medled them selves with wordly af
faires. We have declared in an other
place, how that a writer of the middle
age being made an Abbot, required
that he might leave off from being a
clarke, for that no man could well bee
both a monke and a clarke, since
the one if an impediment to the other.
Then lived they not of the common
revenues of the church, but of ye travel
of their own hand as the lay people do.
S. Jierome disputing of the ori
ginall of monkes in the life of Pau
lus hath thus written: Among ma
ny it hath oftentimes been called into
question, who first began chieflye to
dwell in the wildernes of the monkes?
Some fething the matter somewhat
farre off, beginne to reckon from He
lias the holy Prophet, and Saint John:
of whom Helias seemeth to us to have
beene more than a monke: and that
Saint John began to prophecy before
he was borne. But others (in which o
pinion the most part of all people doe
commonly agree) affirme that Saint
Antonie was the first beginner of
that order: which in part is true. For
he was not onely the first, but also the
motioner of all others thereunto. A
mathas, and Macharius Saint Antonies
scholers, whereof the first buried his
maisters bodie, doe nowe affirme that
one Paulus Thebius was the first be
ginner of that way: which thing wee
also confirme, not onely in name, but
also in opinion. And anon he addeth,
that Paulus forsaking the citie being
thereto enforced for feare of torments
under the persecuters Decius and
Valerianus, departed into the wil
dernesse, where hee found a cave and
lay hidde therein untill he was found
out by S. Antonie. The Emperours
Decius & Valerianus governed ye Em
pyre about the yeere of our Lord 260.
but it is saide that S. Antonie dyed
when he was an hundred & five yeres
olde, in the yeere of our Lord, 360. S.
Augustine, who in his 80 epistle to
Helychiuswitnesseth of his own time
how that hee lived in the yeere of our
Lord, four hundred and twentie.

But Eutropius and Beda reporte
how that hee dyed in the yeere of our
Lorde, foure hundred and thiertye, in
the thirtie and one chapiter, of the ma
ners of the Catholique church, reciting
the manners and institutions of the
monkes in his time, reporteth such
things as are verie farre from the or
ders and institutions of our monkes
nowe a dayes. In the time of Justini
an the Emperour, who made certaine
lawes of Monkes and Monasteries,
there lived once Benet, whome many of
the Monkes now a dayes doe call fa
ther, whose life I will recite unto you
out of Trittenheymius, who died above
fiftie yeeres since, to the intent you
may understand what power and dig
nitie they obeyned in the processe of time,
who at the beginning were contem
ned and of none authoritie. Benet Ab
bat of Caffina, saith he, first founder, be
ginner and governour of the Monkes
in the West, wrote in eloquent, style &
with grave judgement, the rule for
Monkes in one booke, which begin
neth, Give eare O my sone to my pre
ceptes,&c. and it conteyneth three
score and thirteene Chapters. He died
in the yere of our Lord. 542. But Ma
rianus Scotus supposeth that he died in
the yeere of our Lorde. 601. in the last
yeere of the Emperour Mauric.
