He writeth also of twentie orders
of Monkes that were under Benets
rule. Of S. Benets order there have
beene eighteene Popes in the Sea of
Rome. Cardinalls above two hundred.
Archebishops in divers Churches to
the number of one thousand, five hun
dred. Bishops almost four thousand.
Famous Abbats, who excelled in life,
doctrine, and writings, fiftene thou
sand, seven hundred. Of such as are
Canonized, fifteene thousand five hun
dred. And that I may not recite
many other orders of Monkes it is
knowne, that the mendicant Monkes
and Friers, being the faithfull, dili
gent, and valiaunt Romane cham
pions of the Pope, and the spirituall
monarchie, were confirmed by Ho
norrus about the yeere of our Lord, one
thousand, two hundred, twentie and
two. Hereby I would declare nothing
else, but onely that all men should un
derstand that Monkerie was devised
bymans invention, not delivered unto
the Church of Christ by the Apostles:
and that at the first it seemed to bee
tollerable, but afterwarde became
altogether intollerable.

Nowe profitable it is to the com
mon wealth, experience it selfe tea
cheth. And whosoever knoweth not
that it is quite repugnant to true re
ligion, knoweth nothing. They
feigne that it is meritorious before
GOD, and the state of perfection.
But who seeth not how repugnant it
is to Christes merite, and to the sin
cere doctrine of the Gospell? What
godlinesse or necessitie is it that mo
veth us, after that wee have wholy be
taken our selves to one GOD in bap
tisme, to betake our selves also and to
make our vowes to Saintes, and to
blinde our selves by religion of an oth
to ye observing of their rules? True re
ligion forbiddeth us to bow our selves
to Saintes, or by any meanes to de
pend in way of religion upon them.
True religion forbiddeth us any other Fathers or Mai
sters. True religion forbiddeth us to
devise new maners of worshippings,
or new religions, or to receive them
that are devised by others. The ex
ample of Jeroboam and his fellowes.
maketh us affearde. True religion
forbiddeth us to sweare by the names
of other Gods. religion referreth
us to one GOD by faith and obedi
ence. Superstition breaketh this
bande and admitteth creatures. S.
Paule to the Corinthians saith, Eve
rie one of you saith, I am Paules, I
am Apollos, I am Cephaes, and I am
Chriestes. Is Christ divided? was Paul
crucified for you? Or were you bap
tised in the name of Paul? Beholde
Christ is our redeemer and our mai
ster. The faith of Christ hath made
us one bodie. By baptisme wee are
baptised into one body that we might
bee called Christians, not Petrines or
Paulines. S. Paul woulde not suf
fer that Christians shoulde take their
name of the Apostles, how much lesse
would he abide that at this day some
should be called Benedictines, some
Franciscanes, some Dominicanes, wee
are the Lords inheritance and possessi
on: it is not lawful for us to binde our
selves to the service of men. But who
so binde themselves they teare in sun
der ye unitie of Christs body, they pro
phane the crosse & baptisme of Christ.
The Apostle saith plainely, Is Christ
divided? was Paul crucified for you, or
were you baptized in the name of Paul?
And therefore although they be com
monly called spiritual persons, yet are
they nothing lesse than spirituall. For
the Apostle saith, Whe one of you saith,
I am Pauls, & I Apolloes, are ye not
carnal? To what end is it, after ye re
ceyving of the Gospel of Christ Jesus
and the doctrine of the Apostles which
conteine & deliver unto us all godli
nesse, to invent new rules? For truely
when they had once found out certein
peculiar lawes and meanes of living,
they separated them selves from the
common forte of Christians in all
outward manner of living in their be
haviour, and in all their apparell, to
the intent that by they
might make evident to all men, that
they woulde live a-part, as it were,
from that common, laye, and imperfect
Church, to live more holily, perfectly,
and spiritually. But howe well the
same hath framed or doth frame with
them, the whole worlde speaketh it at
this day. The vowes which they bow
are most foolish. They bowe chastitie
which they have not. Chastitie is the
gift of God, and it is not incident to all
men, and S. Paul saith, who so can
not live continently, let him marrie.
For it is better to marrie than to burne.
Generally he saide to burne, whether
it were in a vowe or out of a vowe.
Neither is it lawfull that an humane
vowe and which was foolishly taken
in hand and vowed, should prejudice
the lawe of God. What manner of po
vertie it is which is in Abbeyes, expe
rience it selfe teacheth.

They put off povertie when they
put on their common garmentes, and
with their coule they put on great ri
ches. For monkes, a thing which in
the olde time woulde have seemed a
straunge and monstrous matter, are
made Princes. The common force
of them live idlely, and eat their bread
freely and for nought, against the A
postles rule in the 2. Epistle to the
Thessalonians, cap. 3 where such hee
also accursed, They forsake their pa
rents and kinsfolke, whom by ye law
of God they are bounde to serve and
obey, and betake them selves unto
straunge men by whome they are in
forced to infinitie superstitions.

And they which are thus freely set
at libertie to their parents, either they
are set at libertie through superstiti
on, or so the intent they may have, all
the dayes of their life wherewithall
to lye and rotte in idlenesse. So that it
is evident, that such put on the coule
for their bellies sake, not for any reli
gion. What obedience is that which is
quite contrarie to the obedience which
is revealed by the word of God? When
the magistrate commannded them to
sustaine and heare publique burdens
with the reside of the faithfull, they
be evermore free and exempted. In
olde time, ministers of straunge reli
gions had under the Kinges of Ju
da, princely priviledges and customes
confirmed by presciptio of long time:
but for as much as their ministerie
was not allowed by the word of God,
but was rather repugnant to the
word of God, they were not ungodly,
neither unjustly nor sacrilegiously
broken and divorced by holy kinges.

Who can wel abide to heare their
excuse, who being admonished to doe
penace for the sinnes which they have
committed, make this exception, that
by vertue of their othe they are refer
red to their mokish order so that with
safe conscience they cannot departe
from the same? For it is evident that
the oth which they pretend is altoge
ther a rash oth: which is not to be per
formed as I have declared in the third
sermon of the second Decade. What,
I pray you, can a band which is made
by man without God, yea rather a
gainst the word of God, bindone unto,
specially being made unwisely or bit
advisedly? If the crosse of Christ be of
so great vertue that it hath released
us from the curse unto which we were
all subject, how much more shall it de
liver us from outward bonus where
with we were intrapped not by God,
but other wise through ye follie or wic
kednesse of men, or craft of the divell.

The Apostle S. Paul crieth out, Ye
were bought for a price, become not ye
servats of me. But if happily through
the malice of men, or our owne follie
we become servants, the godly must
endevour that through true faith and
obedience they may be restored to the
libertie of the children of God. Verily
the Gospell is preached unto us, to the
inten we should be delivered from all
unjust captivity and serve God in spi
rite and trueth.

Moreover, where some object that
it were good and convenient that all
monasteries throughout the whole
worlde were reformed and brought
swere, how that in this our unhappie
age it were in vaine, yea plaine follie
to hope for it. They can not bee re
duced to the auncient simplicitie, ney
ther will the Princes and Monkes
suffer such reformation to bee made:
for then they know that they must de
parte not onely with much of their
profites, honours and pleasures, but
with all together. Nowbeit they had
rather that the whole worlde were
together by the eares, than they
would deliver up to God his kingdome,
which they have hither to enjoied. But
admit this thing were easie enough
to accomplish who shall perswade us
that if Abbeyes were reformed ac
cording to the auncient institution,
that in this our age they shoulde bee
as well or better governed than they
were in the olde time? We see what
beginning they had, howe they have
gone forward and how uncreased. We
see what hypocrise, ambition & cove
tousnesse, pleasure and idlenesse coulde
doe, and to what point all thinges are
come. Doe we thinke that mes desires
at this day will bee more moderate?
Doe wee thinke that discipline shall
nowe be lesse corrupted by us and our
posteritie, than it was by our forefa
thers? yea we are constreined not to
hope for ye better, but to feare ye worse,
who every day doe experiment that
which is worse than other. For wee
live in the dregges of the world and in
the verie latter end of all ages, where
in the dragon of the bottomelsse pitte
through the malice and ungodlinesse
of men, hath gotten to himselfe great
power and force to disturbe and cor
rupt all things that are in the whole
worlde. Howebeit in so great perils,
this comforteth us not a litle which is
written in the word of trueth, that for
the electes sake those dayes shall bee
shortened, and that he shalbe loosed for
a short time, and then anon be cast in
to the lake that burneth with fire and
brimstone. Moreover, if we will make
a just reformation, we must needs goe
to the founteines them selves. But in
the primitive church, we reade of no
thing set downe in the doctrine of Christ
and his Apostles concerning monkery,
and thereby we understand that it is
not necessary for the church: yea wee
have learned by experience that it is
noysome and hurtfull to the Church.
Wherefore, true reformation per
swadeth us altogether to abrogate
monkerie: not rejecting or neglecting
in the meane season such as doe repent
whom the wickednes of the time hath
made unprofitable both for theselves
and others, but gently to receive them
into the care and almes of the church.
Thus much hitherto have we said by
occasion, and as it were by the way.
concerning monkertie, which we have
declared to have had no place in ye pri
mitive church of Christ and his Apo
stles. Let us therefore returne to other
necessarie institutions of the church.

Likewise the faithfull Church of
Christ usedth discipline about the
sicke, and such as are departing out
of this life. There come about them
neighbours and brethren, and every
one for his part sheweth ye dueties of
love and charitie: they releive the nee
die with their goodes, and if the sicke
be not needie then doe they shew other
dueties of good will. There commeth
also the minister of the Church, who
in comforting the sicke person prepa
reth him to die by making first his co
fession of sinnes to God which hee pro
nounceth out of the word of God to be
forgiven if he doe stedfastly believe.

He requireth of him also that hee
forgive, and bee in love and charitie
with all men, and that hee keepe no
olde grudge or malice in his heart. Af
ter this, some publique prayer is made
to God by ye sicke person, and by those
that are about the partie that is at the
point of death. Hee is also admonished
of sundrie thinges, he is confirmed in
the faith, he is called to patience, hee
is instructed according as his goods,
and everie thing else requireth, and he
is taught that at his departing out of
this worlde, he commend his soule in
to the handes of God the father, accor
ding to ye doctrine and example of our
redeemer who at the verie point of
death cryed aloude, saying, Father in
to thy handes I cocmmend my spirite.

This discipline have wee learned
of the Apostles of our Lorde Christ.
For the Apostle Saint James saith,
If any be sicke among you, let him send
for the elders of the Church and let
him pray over him, annointing him
with oyle in the name of the Lorde.
And the prayer which is made in faith,
shall deliver the sick. And the Lorde
shall raise him up again.

And if he be in sinne, they shall bee
forgiven him. Confesse your sinnes one
of you to another: and pray one for an
other, that you may bee safe, for the
heartie prayer of the just is of greate
force, &c. This is the Apostolique dis
cipline. But if you say unto mee,
Where is the oyle? I answere, that
in Saint James the Apostles time, and
certaine ages after, there remayned
yet in the Church the myraculous gift
of healing the sicke. Of this we read in
Saint Markes Gospell And the disci
ples going forth preached the Gos
pell that they might repent, and they
cast out many devils, and they annoin
ted many with oile, that were sicke and
healed them, And againe in the same
place, saith, Moreover, These signes
shall follow them that beleeve. In my
name they shal cast out devils, &c. And
anon he saith, They shal lay their hands
upon the sicke, and they shalbe healed.
And because this benefite remayned
yet in the Church, Saint James biddeth
us use oyle, and to use it in the name
of the Lord, as the Lord had comman
ded. But seeing that gift is now ceassed
in the Churche, and wee finde by ex
perience that oyle doth not good to the
sicke, according to the time, and as our
duetie bindeth as we doe the best wee
can to all wage and cure the diseases of
the sicke by medicines most covenient
for the sickenes, being applied in the
name of Christ.

I knowe howe by this testimonie
of the Apostle, the Papistes goe about
to set out and commend their extreame
unction, or last annoyting: but they
labour in vaine. But to let passe that
Saint James speaketh nothing of the
hallowed oyle: and that they doe not
admitte this medicine but in verie ex
tremity where Saint James comman
deth to annoint everieone that is sick
how, I pray you, can they defende out
of Saint James wordes that which
the Priest demandeth of the sicke per
son, Doest thou beleeve that the Lord
wil heare our praiers for ye merits sake,
& praiers of the Saints? The sicke man
answering I do beleeve. He then saith,
Let us therefore pray to God and his
Saintes. Or where, I beseech you hath
Saint James or any other Apostle of
Christ taught that which they bring
in their annointing? In the name of
the father, and of the sonne and of the
holy Ghost, I annoint thee with holie
oile, that by this annointing thou masit
receive full remission of thy sinnes.
What scripture I pray you, teacheth
us, that full remission of sinnes is ob
teined by that annoynting? These
things are done manifestly against the
principal article of our religion, which
teacheth that we are purged from all
our sinnes only by the blood of Christ,
and that most fully. To him onely is
the glorie due, not to the oyle, nor to
any creature in the whole world.

Moreover, the Church of Christe
doth not reject the bodies of the dead,
as if it were a dead dogge. For it ac
knowledgeth that their bodies have
beene the Temples of the holy Ghost,
which hath dwelt in them. I acknow
ledgeth that they are buried in hope
of resurrection and glorie of life ever
lasting, wherefore the Church doeth
in most reverend manner take the
bodyes, windeth them in a sheete, and
covereth them verie decentlye, and
being put into the coffine careful
lye carrieth them unto teh place of
burial of churchyard, ye neere friendes,
neighbours and brethren following
after, and accompanying the corse.

While the bodie is set downe and
laid in the earth, there are publique
praiers made by them that brought the
corse. For they give thanks unto God,
for that he hath called the party decea
sed out of this world in the true faith,
and they pray also that it may please
the Lord to take them likewise unto
him speedily, being lightened with the
true faith.

Moreover, the name of the dead bro
ther or sister is recited in the publique
assemblie of the church with honour, &
all the people are put in minde of their
owne destinie, and speedily to prepare
them selves to die. And after this ma
ner, we read in the scriptures, that the
ancient fathers burief their dead, yea,
the most holy of them.

We read nothing of canonizating,
of worshipping of reliques, of moneths
and yeeres mindes for the dead, which
are suffered to the end of the soules of the
departed should be delivered from the
paines of purgatorie.

There be certaine burials descri
bed unto us in the olde Testament, as
the buriall of Abraham, Sara, Isaac,
Jacob, and Joseph, Aaron, Marie, Jo
shua, Samuel, & David, &c. And in the
new Testament of John Baptist, and
Stephan, but they were all sparing,
& without all manner of superstition.

In that Josephes bones were car
ried forth, they were caried in a my
terie, that the Israelites might gather
thereof, that they should be brought in
to the land of promise.

Whereunto also that belongeth that
the patriarches chose a buriall in
Hebron. Otherwise they place avay
leth nothing to purchase the better or
worse speed to the bodie that is buried
in it. We must thinke that the place
by reason of the bodies of the Saintes
and holy men which are their buried
is after a manner sanctified, us at the
leastwise called holy: not that the bo
dies do get any holines or safety by the
groud. Therefore unlesse it seeme good
otherwise to the divine providence of
God, the Sainctes would gladly lie
with their auncestours in the selfe
same place of buriall.

But if it please God otherwise, they
acknowledge that they are notwith
standing received into the same earth,
without any exception, and that they
are not separated from their aunce
stours by distance of place. Wherefore
their is no superstition in the Church
of God about burials and graves. But
how much there was in the time of
Poperie, no man can declare in fewe
wordes.

These bee the necessarie instituti
ons of the Church of GOD, and are
by the faithfull religiously observed
without supersition, to edification: as
for other matters which are onely de
vised by the invention of man, the
godlie nothing weigh them. I know
what thinges may here bee objected.
That forsooth, the auncient people of
the olde Testament had sundrie and
manifold rites & ceremonies institu
ted of God by his Prophetes, because
being rude they had neede of such in
struction. But since the common
sorte of Christians are also more rude
than is to be wished, so many sundrie
and diverse ceremonies were devi
sed by the auncient fathers not with
out the motion of the spirit, which they
must also obey. I answere, that this is
no true nor sounde reason, whereby
the weake in faith may receive com
moditie. For surely the would not the
Apostles of Christ have saide nothing
thereof. Moreover experience teacheth
that the state & condition of the weake
and simple is such, that the more cere
monies are left unto them, the more
their minds are diversly dispersed, and
are lefte united to Christ, to whome a
long all things are to be ascribed. For
it pleased the Father that all fulnesse
should dwell in him, and to heape to
gether in him all things appertaining
to our life and salvation. Yea, the Di
vine wisedom of God hath take away
that whole externall discipline and in
struction, setting a difference betwene
us and them. We should therefore pro
ceede to bring againe Judaisme, if wee
should not leave off to multiply & heap
together rises and ceremonies, accor
ding to the manner of the olde church.
For in old time those ceremonies we
had in use, although they were not in
finite, but comprised within a certaine
number. At this present there is no use
nor place for them in the Church. Nei
ther doe we want most grave authori
tie to prove the same. The Apostles &
Elders in a great aseemblie meet toge
ther at Jierusalem at a coucell, where
the Apostle plainely telleth them that
they tempt ye Lord in going about to
lay the yoke of the lawe upon the free
neckers of the Christians. There is al
so a Synodall Espistle written, where
in by one consent they testiffe that it
hath seemed good to the holy Ghost and
them to lay none other burthen uppon
the Church of Christ, than that which
they recite in fewe wordes. To the in
ten thereby it may be evident, that ye
doctrine of the Gospel is sufficient for
the church, without the ceremonies of
the law. If he would not then have ye
rites which in olde times were by God
instituted, to bee joyned to the Gospel,
how much lesse ought we at this preset
to couple therewith the inventions of
men? Unto which moreover is wic
kedly ascribed, either the preparation,
to the grace, & worshipping of God, or
part of our salvation, that we may say
no lesse at this day, than S. Paul said
long agoe, After that you have known
God, how chanceth it that ye returne
againe to weake & beggerly elemets,
which you woulde beginne to serve a
new? Ye observe daies and moneths,
times & yeeres. I am afeard least I have
taken paines about you in vaine. Unto
al these things this is also to be added,
that this instruction of ceremonies,
whereof they speake, belongeth to the
worshipping of God. But wee are for
bidden to devise unto our selves anye
strange worshipping: we are forbidden
also to put too, or take away any thing
from the institution or worde of God.
Wherefore, ye church of God, neither or
deineth, nor receiveth of any other such
costitutios. Of which matter we have
also spoken some what before, whereas
we intreated of the abrogating of the
Law, and of Christian liberty.

I trust that in these fifty Sermons,
I have as shortly and conveniently as
might be, coprehended the whole mat
ter of faith, godlines, or true religion, &
also of the Church. That which I doe
often repeate in al my sermons, & my
bookes, that do I also againe repeat in
this place, that the learned may with
my good wil & thanks gather and im
brace better things out of ye scriptures.
Unto the Lord our God, ye everlasting
fountaine of al goodnesse, be praise, and
glory, through our Lord Jesus Christ.
Amen.
Finis.
